bullets.text: Machine Learning (ML) is a subfield of Artificial Intelligence (AI).
ML systems learn patterns from data rather than being programmed with fixed rules.
Models improve over time with more data without needing reprogramming.
It's about teaching computers to learn from experience, similar to humans.
Machine learning is ubiquitous, powering recommendations, spam filters, and virtual assistants.
Its popularity stems from access to vast amounts of data.
Increased computational power (GPUs) enables efficient data processing.
Sophisticated algorithms have been developed to extract insights from data.
The most common type, trained using labeled data (input + correct output).
Model learns the relationship to predict outputs for new, unseen inputs.
Example: predicting house prices based on features and actual sale prices.
Regression predicts continuous values (e.g., price, temperature).
Classification predicts discrete labels or categories (e.g., spam detection).
Uses data without labeled outputs, only inputs are provided.
Goal is for the algorithm to discover patterns or structures on its own.
Clustering groups similar data points, like customers by buying behavior.
Dimensionality reduction simplifies data with many features (e.g., PCA).
An agent learns by interacting with an environment.
Receives feedback as rewards or penalties and adjusts its strategy.
Goal is to learn a policy that maximizes total reward over time.
Examples include training robots to walk or AI playing games like chess (AlphaGo).
Data quality is crucial; noisy, biased, or incomplete data degrades performance.
Overfitting occurs when a model learns training data too well but fails on new data.
Ethical concerns arise from biased data leading to biased models with real-world consequences.
Understanding data, context, and impact is as important as the algorithms.
Recap of ML definition, importance, three types, and challenges.
Future lectures will delve deeper into each ML type and algorithms.
